goals.question: What is the overall trend of unemployment across industries?
goals.visualization: Line chart showing the trend of unemployment rate across industries over time
goals.rationale: This visualization helps to identify the industries that have been most affected by unemployment over time.

goals.question: Which industry has the highest unemployment rate?
goals.visualization: Bar chart showing the unemployment rate for each industry
goals.rationale: This visualization helps to identify the industry with the highest unemployment rate, which can be useful for policymakers and job seekers.

goals.question: What is the relationship between education level and unemployment rate?
goals.visualization: Scatter plot showing the relationship between education level and unemployment rate
goals.rationale: This visualization helps to identify the relationship between education level and unemployment rate, which can be useful for policymakers and educators.

goals.question: What is the distribution of unemployment rate across industries?
goals.visualization: Histogram showing the distribution of unemployment rate across industries
goals.rationale: This visualization helps to identify the industries with the highest and lowest unemployment rates, which can be useful for policymakers and job seekers.

goals.question: What is the average unemployment rate across industries?
goals.visualization: Box plot showing the distribution of unemployment rate across industries
goals.rationale: This visualization helps to identify the average unemployment rate across industries and the variability of unemployment rates within each industry.

code:
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
import pandas as pd

def plot(data: pd.DataFrame):
    data['date'] = pd.to_datetime(data['date'], errors='coerce')
    data = data[pd.notna(data['date'])]
    
    industries = data['industry'].unique()
    for industry in industries:
        industry_data = data[data['industry'] == industry]
        plt.plot(industry_data['date'], industry_data['unemployment_rate'], label=industry)
    
    plt.title('What is the overall trend of unemployment across industries?', wrap=True)
    plt.xlabel('Date')
    plt.ylabel('Unemployment Rate')
    plt.xticks(rotation=45)
    plt.legend(title='Industries', loc='upper left')
    return plt;

chart = plot(data)

import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
import pandas as pd

def plot(data: pd.DataFrame):
    data = data.sort_values(by='unemployment_rate', ascending=False)
    ax = data.plot.bar(x='industry', y='unemployment_rate', legend=False)
    plt.title('Which industry has the highest unemployment rate?')
    plt.xlabel('Industry')
    plt.ylabel('Unemployment Rate')
    plt.xticks(rotation=45)
    plt.axhline(data['unemployment_rate'].max(), color='r', linestyle='--', label=f"Max: {data['unemployment_rate'].max():.2f}")
    plt.legend()
    return plt;

chart = plot(data)

import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
import pandas as pd

def plot(data: pd.DataFrame):
    data.plot(kind='scatter', x='education_level', y='unemployment_rate', c='industry', colormap='viridis', legend=True)
    plt.title("What is the relationship between education level and unemployment rate?", wrap=True)
    plt.xticks(rotation=45)
    plt.xlabel("Education Level")
    plt.ylabel("Unemployment Rate")
    return plt;

chart = plot(data)

import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
import pandas as pd

def plot(data: pd.DataFrame):
    data['unemployment_rate'] = pd.to_numeric(data['unemployment_rate'], errors='coerce')
    data = data[pd.notna(data['unemployment_rate'])]
    
    plt.hist(data['unemployment_rate'], bins=20, color='blue', alpha=0.7, label='Unemployment Rate')
    plt.axvline(data['unemployment_rate'].median(), color='red', linestyle='dashed', linewidth=2, label=f"Median: {data['unemployment_rate'].median():.2f}")
    
    plt.xlabel('Unemployment Rate')
    plt.ylabel('Frequency')
    plt.title('What is the distribution of unemployment rate across industries?', wrap=True)
    plt.legend()
    
    return plt;

chart = plot(data)

import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
import pandas as pd

def plot(data: pd.DataFrame):
    data['date'] = pd.to_datetime(data['date'], errors='coerce')
    data = data[pd.notna(data['date'])]
    
    fig, ax = plt.subplots()
    data.boxplot(column='unemployment_rate', by='industry', ax=ax, grid=False)
    ax.set_title('What is the average unemployment rate across industries?')
    ax.set_xlabel('Industry')
    ax.set_ylabel('Unemployment Rate')
    plt.xticks(rotation=45)
    plt.suptitle('')
    plt.legend(title='Industries', loc='upper right')
    
    return plt;

chart = plot(data)
